issue.title: [Bug?]: React rendering warnings from upgrade-interactive
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

This bug relates to the upgrade-interactive UI, which is built with React (via [Ink](https://github.com/vadimdemedes/ink)).

It's throwing React rendering errors about unique keys, which is pretty common in React apps. I think this particular issue is rare, but I happen to have a set of available upgrades that provokes it.

Here's the symptom (which appears above the interactive terminal UI):

```
Warning: Encountered two children with the same key, `^7.0.0`. Keys should be unique so that components maintain their identity across updates. Non-unique keys may cause children to be duplicated and/or omitted — the behavior is unsupported and could change in a future version.
    in $5 (created by W)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by W)
    in W (created by ne)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in m4 (created by ne)
    in ne
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box
    in Unknown
    in kx
    in InternalApp
```

And here's what it's rendering:

```
 Press <up>/<down> to select packages.            Press <enter> to install.
 Press <left>/<right> to select versions.         Press <ctrl+c> to abort.

? Pick the packages you want to upgrade.          Current          Range            Latest

 > @storybook/react-vite ----------------------- ◉ ^7.0.0-alpha.… ◯ ^7.0.0 ------- ◯ ^7.0.0 -------
   @storybook/react ---------------------------- ◉ ^7.0.0-alpha.… ◯ ^7.0.0 ------- ◯ ^6.5.13 ------
```

(Notice that the string `^7.0.0` appears a few times)

Skimming through [upgrade-interactive.tsx](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/blob/%40yarnpkg/shell/3.2.4/packages/plugin-interactive-tools/sources/commands/upgrade-interactive.tsx), I don't see many explicit keys provided (`key={something_here}`), so perhaps this relates to the way Ink behaves when they're left out. (using the contained text instead?)

### To reproduce

Minimal package.json:
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "@storybook/react": "^7.0.0-alpha.44",
    "@storybook/react-vite": "^7.0.0-alpha.44"
  },
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.4"
}
```

`yarn set version stable`
`yarn plugin import interactive-tools`
`yarn install`
`yarn upgrade-interactive`

This repro also depends on the available package versions - I imagine the issue may go away when Storybook begins stable 7.0.x releases.

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 13.0
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.17.1 - /private/var/folders/f1/5hh6j9fd7mv6dm1hdrzzh7_w0000gn/T/xfs-e4bcc5e6/node
    Yarn: 3.2.4 - /private/var/folders/f1/5hh6j9fd7mv6dm1hdrzzh7_w0000gn/T/xfs-e4bcc5e6/yarn
    npm: 8.15.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.17.1/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
Hi! 👋

This issue looks stale, and doesn't feature the `reproducible` label - which implies that you didn't provide a working reproduction using [Sherlock](https://yarnpkg.com/advanced/sherlock). As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. Sherlock gives us the ability to check which bugs are still affecting the master branch at any given point, and decreases the amount of code we need to run on our own machines (thus leading to faster bug resolutions). It helps us help you! 😃

If you absolutely *cannot* reproduce a bug on Sherlock (for example because it's a Windows-only issue), a maintainer will have to manually add the `upholded` label. Thanks for helping us triaging our repository! 🌟

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When:
- use `yarn` command to install a dependence package from Git Source;
- there are **no build scripts** in the git package; 
- there is a dev dependence package whose descriptor is `"workspace:*"`, and it's not hosted in the repository of the git package.

what happens:
- `yarn` failed with YN0058.

issue.title: [Bug?]: Yarn with pnp linker wants to delete mountpoint of `node_modules/.cache`
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

yarn berry want to delete docker volume

### To reproduce

```sh
$ cd `mktemp -d`
$ g=node:18.11.0-alpine3.16@sha256:828424b660b8274e7dcf6c7447f014406610facf663f38df92c3162a3d29a1db
$ mkdir -p node_modules
$
$ docker run --rm -it -v "$PWD":/app  -v node_modules:/app/node_modules -w /app "$g" sh
/app # apk add git
/app # yarn init -2
/app # yarn --version
3.2.4
/app # node --version
v18.11.0
/app # yarn
➤ YN0000: ┌ Resolution step
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
➤ YN0000: ┌ Fetch step
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
➤ YN0000: ┌ Link step
➤ YN0031: │ One or more node_modules have been detected and will be removed. This operation may take some time.
➤ YN0001: │ Error: EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/app/node_modules'
➤ YN0000: └ Completed in 1s 24ms
➤ YN0000: Failed with errors in 1s 73ms
```

```
$ yarn
Error: EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/path/to/node_modules'
```

### Environment

```shell
$ yarn --version
3.2.4
$ node --version
18.9.1
```


### Additional context

https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/issues/4259
https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/issues/4172

comment.body:
Hi! 👋

This issue looks stale, and doesn't feature the `reproducible` label - which implies that you didn't provide a working reproduction using [Sherlock](https://yarnpkg.com/advanced/sherlock). As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. Sherlock gives us the ability to check which bugs are still affecting the master branch at any given point, and decreases the amount of code we need to run on our own machines (thus leading to faster bug resolutions). It helps us help you! 😃

If you absolutely *cannot* reproduce a bug on Sherlock (for example because it's a Windows-only issue), a maintainer will have to manually add the `upholded` label. Thanks for helping us triaging our repository! 🌟

### Self-service

### Describe the bug

Installing `typescript@4.9.3` with `yarn@3.2.4` results in many spurious type errors when tsc is run.

### To reproduce

```js repro

await packageJsonAndInstall({
    dependencies: {
        typescript: '4.8.4'
    }
})

await packageJsonAndInstall({
    dependencies: {
        typescript: '4.9.3'
    }
})
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 13.0.1
    CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro

    npm: 8.19.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v18.12.1/bin/npm
```

issue.title: [Bug?]: Duplicate same version dependency when parents peerDependencies are different
issue.body: ### Self-service - [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix ### Describe the bug | 1st level dependency | `react-draggable` version range | `peerDependencies` | |---|---|---| | [react-grid-layout@1.3.4](https://github.com/react-grid-layout/react-grid-layout) | `^4.0.0` | `{ "react": ">= 16.3.0", "react-dom": ">= 16.3.0" }` | | [react-resizable@1.4.5](https://github.com/react-grid-layout/react-resizable) | `^4.0.3` | `{ "react": ">= 16.3" }` | ```shell ⋊> ~/w/r/e/test-yarn3-duplicates on master ⨯ yarn why react-draggable -R └─ test-yarn3-duplicates@workspace:. └─ react-grid-layout@npm:1.3.4 [8f25d] (via npm:^1.3.4 [8f25d]) ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [6c42a] (via npm:^4.0.0 [6c42a]) └─ react-resizable@npm:3.0.4 [6c42a] (via npm:^3.0.4 [6c42a]) └─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [5d025] (via npm:^4.0.3 [5d025]) ``` ```shell ⋊> ~/w/r/e/test-yarn3-duplicates on master ⨯ yarn info -AR --virtuals react-draggable ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 │ ├─ Instances: 2 │ ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ │ │ └─ Dependencies │ ├─ clsx@npm:^1.1.1 → npm:1.2.1 │ └─ prop-types@npm:^15.8.1 → npm:15.8.1 │ ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [5d025] │ ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ │ │ └─ Peer dependencies │ ├─ @types/react-dom@* → ✘ │ ├─ @types/react@* → ✘ │ ├─ react-dom@>= 16.3.0 → ✘ │ └─ react@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 │ └─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [6c42a] ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ └─ Peer dependencies ├─ @types/react-dom@* → ✘ ├─ @types/react@* → ✘ ├─ react-dom@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 [8f25d] └─ react@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 ``` Webpack stats modules ([full bundle analysis](https://bit.ly/3EIdKKK)): ### To reproduce Example repo: https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates Happy to add some reproducible tests if need it ;) ### Environment ```shell System: OS: macOS 12.5.1 CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro Binaries: Node: 18.7.0 - /private/var/folders/wf/b3whd19d2hs648_qm9tv046h0000gp/T/xfs-7b5b57ae/node Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/wf/b3whd19d2hs648_qm9tv046h0000gp/T/xfs-7b5b57ae/yarn ``` ### Additional context I was able to workaround the problem using `packageExtensions`: 1. https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates/pull/6 2. https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates/pull/8

issue.title: [Bug?]: `yarn workspace version apply` removes deferred versions for other packages
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

I have a workspace that has two packages which do not share a release cycle.

I'm using deferred versioning on the packages with `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version <strategy> --deferred`, which creates `.yarn/versions/<hash>.yml` files defining the strategy just for my target workspace, as I would expect.

When I run `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version apply`, the `package.json` file for the specified workspace is updated. As expected, the `package.json` for the other workspaces has not changed. However, the `.yarn/versions` files have removed the other deferred changes.

### To reproduce

I created a minimal repo using yarn berry with a workspace: https://github.com/NikkiDelRosso/yarn-workspace-version-deferred-issue

1. Clone the repo above
2. Run `yarn workspace package-b version apply`
3. See that the `packages/package-b/package.json` version number has been bumped
4. See that the `packages/package-a/package.json` version number has not changed (this is expected)
5. See that the `package-a: patch` line in in `.yarn/versions/27f417a6.yml` has been removed
6. Run `yarn workspace package-a version apply`
7. Receive a message indicating that there is no version bump available for the workspace (even though it should have had been bumped for a patch)


### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.5.1
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/node
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.15.1/bin/npm
```


<!-- ### Additional context


<details><summary>Details: git diff showing relevant changed files after running `yarn workspace package-b version apply` on my example repo (click to expand)</summary>

```diff

--- a/.yarn/versions/9fb57f43.yml

@@ -1,2 +0,0 @@

issue.title: [Feature] --visual-verbose

labels.name: waiting for feedback
labels.description: Will autoclose in a while unless more data are provided

issue.body:
Hello !

Instead of the --verbose flag outputting a lot of text that breaks around in the terminal and even if it would be structured I wouldn't understand

I WOULD LIKE: more verbose progress bars

Ideally like a arc/circle diagram that is rather big and that fills up clockwise. This should be optimized for very slow connections (remember that large part of the world does have no or slow internet)

So this circle should move a lot and fill up with the dumbest tasks.

One heuristic of implementing this could be that for every line that would be displayed in verbose mode in the terminal, the circle arc should increase by 5%

There should be 2 things

A global progress indicator as a bar
A subtask-progress indicator as a circle or arc

This way the user would see the dumbest slowest progress and everybody would understand

That would truly be in improvement

Because now it is either

Waiting 10 minutes in the darkness
OR: having the screen full of garbage potentially slowing everything down

Thanks

issue.title: [Bug?]: yarn pack doesn't include all the files

labels.name: reproducible
labels.description: This issue can be successfully reproduced

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

`yarn pack` doesn't include all the files for the [mediasoup](https://github.com/versatica/mediasoup/) project. This only happens on Yarn v3. Yarn v1 and NPM pack them correctly. This leads to install failure when this package is installed directly from GitHub. 

On v3, `yarn pack` will only include files, if they are directly specified or match a pattern in `package.json#files`. Specifying just the folder name doesn't work:

It won't pack all the files in `worker/src` and `worker/include`
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include",
    "worker/src",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",
    "worker/meson.build",
    "worker/meson_options.txt",
    "npm-scripts.js"
  ],
```

But if try wildcard patterns, it includes them:
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include/**/*",
    "worker/src/**/*",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",
    "worker/meson.build",
    "worker/meson_options.txt",
    "npm-scripts.js"
  ],
```

### To reproduce

- Download the `mediasoup` tarball from github:
	```sh
	$ wget https://github.com/versatica/mediasoup/tarball/3.10.9  
	$ tar -xzvf 3.10.9 
	$ cd versatica-mediasoup-bf3fd4d
	```
- Check what files should be present in the archives:
	```
	$ cat package.json | grep files -C20
	  "main": "node/lib/index.js",
	  "types": "node/lib/index.d.ts",
	  "files": [
	    "node/lib",
	    "worker/deps/libwebrtc",
	    "worker/fuzzer/include",
	    "worker/fuzzer/src",
	    "worker/include",
	    "worker/scripts/*.py",
	    "worker/scripts/*.sh",
	    "worker/scripts/*.js",
	    "worker/scripts/*.json",
	    "worker/src",
	    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
	    "worker/test/include",
	    "worker/test/src",
	    "worker/Makefile",
	    "worker/meson.build",
	    "worker/meson_options.txt",
	    "npm-scripts.js"
	  ],
	```

-  Pack it with yarn 3.2.4. `worker/src` and `worker/include` folder are missing:
	```
	$ yarn pack --dry-run
	➤ YN0000: CHANGELOG.md
	➤ YN0000: LICENSE
	➤ YN0000: README.md
	➤ YN0000: node/lib/index.js
	➤ YN0000: npm-scripts.js
	➤ YN0000: package.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/Makefile
	➤ YN0000: worker/meson.build
	➤ YN0000: worker/meson_options.txt
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/clang-tidy.py
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/cppcheck.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/cpu_cores.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/flint++.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/get-dep.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/gulpfile.js
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/lcov.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/package-lock.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/package.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/abseil-cpp.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/catch2.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/libsrtp2.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/libuv.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/nlohmann_json.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/openssl.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/usrsctp.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/wingetopt.wrap
	➤ YN0000: Done in 0s 208ms
	```
- Running `yarn pack` with yarn 1.22.11 works and has all the files:
	```
	$ corepack prepare yarn@1.22.11 --activate
	$ yarn pack
	yarn pack v1.22.11
	success Wrote tarball to "/Users/niksrc/Downloads/versatica-mediasoup-bf3fd4d/mediasoup-v3.10.9.tgz".
	✨  Done in 0.34s.
	$ tar -ztf mediasoup-v3.10.9.tgz
	package
	package/CHANGELOG.md

	package/README.md

issue.title: [Bug?]: yarn pack doesn't include all the files

labels.name: unreproducible
labels.description: This issue cannot be reproduced on master

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

`yarn pack` doesn't include all the files for the [mediasoup](https://github.com/versatica/mediasoup/) project. This only happens on Yarn v3. Yarn v1 and NPM pack them correctly. This leads to install failure when this package is installed directly from GitHub. 

On v3, `yarn pack` will only include files, if they are directly specified or match a pattern in `package.json#files`. Specifying just the folder name doesn't work:

It won't pack all the files in `worker/src` and `worker/include`
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include",
    "worker/src",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",
    "worker/meson.build",
    "worker/meson_options.txt",
    "npm-scripts.js"
  ],
```

But if try wildcard patterns, it includes them:
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include/**/*",
    "worker/src/**/*",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",
    "worker/meson.build",
    "worker/meson_options.txt",
    "npm-scripts.js"
  ],
```

### To reproduce

- Download the `mediasoup` tarball from github:
	```sh
	$ wget https://github.com/versatica/mediasoup/tarball/3.10.9  
	$ tar -xzvf 3.10.9 
	$ cd versatica-mediasoup-bf3fd4d
	```
- Check what files should be present in the archives:
	```
	$ cat package.json | grep files -C20
	  "main": "node/lib/index.js",
	  "types": "node/lib/index.d.ts",
	  "files": [
	    "node/lib",
	    "worker/deps/libwebrtc",
	    "worker/fuzzer/include",
	    "worker/fuzzer/src",
	    "worker/include",
	    "worker/scripts/*.py",
	    "worker/scripts/*.sh",
	    "worker/scripts/*.js",
	    "worker/scripts/*.json",
	    "worker/src",
	    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
	    "worker/test/include",
	    "worker/test/src",
	    "worker/Makefile",
	    "worker/meson.build",
	    "worker/meson_options.txt",
	    "npm-scripts.js"
	  ],
	```

-  Pack it with yarn 3.2.4. `worker/src` and `worker/include` folder are missing:
	```
	$ yarn pack --dry-run
	➤ YN0000: CHANGELOG.md
	➤ YN0000: LICENSE
	➤ YN0000: README.md
	➤ YN0000: node/lib/index.js
	➤ YN0000: npm-scripts.js
	➤ YN0000: package.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/Makefile
	➤ YN0000: worker/meson.build
	➤ YN0000: worker/meson_options.txt
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/clang-tidy.py
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/cppcheck.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/cpu_cores.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/flint++.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/get-dep.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/gulpfile.js
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/lcov.sh
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/package-lock.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/scripts/package.json
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/abseil-cpp.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/catch2.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/libsrtp2.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/libuv.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/nlohmann_json.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/openssl.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/usrsctp.wrap
	➤ YN0000: worker/subprojects/wingetopt.wrap
	➤ YN0000: Done in 0s 208ms
	```
- Running `yarn pack` with yarn 1.22.11 works and has all the files:
	```
	$ corepack prepare yarn@1.22.11 --activate
	$ yarn pack
	yarn pack v1.22.11
	success Wrote tarball to "/Users/niksrc/Downloads/versatica-mediasoup-bf3fd4d/mediasoup-v3.10.9.tgz".

issue.title: What determines the resolution hash value? Seeing differences on CI vs locally for local package

labels.name: waiting for feedback
labels.description: Will autoclose in a while unless more data are provided

issue.body:
### Discussed in https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/discussions/2605
Originally posted by **ercgrat** March 16, 2021 Created a package within a package to create a custom eslint plugin. Added it like so: `yarn add --dev ./eslint`. The resulting `yarn.lock` entry contains a checksum. When `yarn` is run on CI and on GitHub actions, there is no checksum and the hash value in `resolution` is also different. What's accounting for this and can I control it? I realize creating a true repo and publishing this eslint package would be a workaround, but seems silly for a one-liner. The actual error I see is: `YN0028: │ The lockfile would have been modified by this install, which is explicitly forbidden.` These are the only two resources I have found that seem relevant: https://github.com/yarnpkg/yarn/issues/1916 https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49501749/is-it-possible-to-ignore-the-dependency-hash-validation-of-just-one-module-or-r

issue.title: [Bug?]: `yarn workspace version apply` removes deferred versions for other packages
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

I have a workspace that has two packages which do not share a release cycle.

I'm using deferred versioning on the packages with `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version <strategy> --deferred`, which creates `.yarn/versions/<hash>.yml` files defining the strategy just for my target workspace, as I would expect.

When I run `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version apply`, the `package.json` file for the specified workspace is updated. As expected, the `package.json` for the other workspaces has not changed. However, the `.yarn/versions` files have removed the other deferred changes.

### To reproduce

I created a minimal repo using yarn berry with a workspace: https://github.com/NikkiDelRosso/yarn-workspace-version-deferred-issue

1. Clone the repo above
2. Run `yarn workspace package-b version apply`
3. See that the `packages/package-b/package.json` version number has been bumped
4. See that the `packages/package-a/package.json` version number has not changed (this is expected)
5. See that the `package-a: patch` line in in `.yarn/versions/27f417a6.yml` has been removed
6. Run `yarn workspace package-a version apply`
7. Receive a message indicating that there is no version bump available for the workspace (even though it should have had been bumped for a patch)


### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.5.1
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/node
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.15.1/bin/npm
```

issue.title: [Feature] --visual-verbose

labels.name: waiting for feedback
labels.description: Will autoclose in a while unless more data are provided

issue.body:
Hello !

Instead of the --verbose flag outputting a lot of text that breaks around in the terminal and even if it would be structured I wouldn't understand

I WOULD LIKE: more verbose progress bars

Ideally like a arc/circle diagram that is rather big and that fills up clockwise. This should be optimized for very slow connections (remember that large part of the world does have no or slow internet)

So this circle should move a lot and fill up with the dumbest tasks.

One heuristic of implementing this could be that for every line that would be displayed in verbose mode in the terminal, the circle arc should increase by 5%

There should be 2 things

A global progress indicator as a bar
A subtask-progress indicator as a circle or arc

This way the user would see the dumbest slowest progress and everybody would understand

That would truly be in improvement

Because now it is either

Waiting 10 minutes in the darkness
OR: having the screen full of garbage potentially slowing everything down

Thanks

issue.title: [Bug?]: Checksum mismatch between corepack and non-corepack installs because of newline in package.json

labels.name: broken-repro
labels.description: The reproduction in this issue is broken

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When switching between `corepack enable` and `corepack disable`, Yarn complains about a checksum mismatch on a package installed with the `git:` protocol. This seems to be because the packing happens with a different version of Yarn, which adds / removes an extra newline at the end of the `package.json` of the dependency.

I had a similar problem before with Yarn 3.2.1 (adding a `packageManager` field to the package.json, IIRC). I upgraded to v3.2.3, which should have resolved that problem, but now I have this.

### To reproduce

Steps to reproduce:
- Create a new, empty directory
- Create the following `package.json`:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  }
}
```
- `yarn set version berry` or `yarn set version from sources` (I could reproduce with both)
- `corepack disable`
- `yarn`
- `corepack enable` (you can switch these around - first enable, then disable fails for me too)
- `rm -rf node_modules`
- `yarn cache clean --all`
- `yarn` -> fails with `YN0018: │ timecop@https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#commit=d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761: The remote archive doesn't match the expected checksum`

I tried to make a reproducible case with Sherlock, as suggested - I made this, but it works fine there:
```js repro
const path = require('path')
const {execFile} = require(`child_process`)
const {promisify} = require(`util`)

const execFileP = promisify(execFile)

async function exec(execPath, args = [], opts = {}) {
  try {
    const {stdout} = await execFileP(execPath, args, opts)
    return stdout
  } catch (error) {
    error.message += `\n${error.stdout}`;
    throw error;
  }
};

await packageJson({
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  },
})

const nodePath = process.argv[0]
const corepackPath = path.resolve(nodePath, '../corepack')

await yarn('set', 'version', 'berry')
await exec(corepackPath, ['enable'])
await yarn('install', '--inline-builds')

await exec(corepackPath, ['disable'])
await exec('rm', ['-rf', 'node_modules'])
await yarn('cache', 'clean', '--all')
await expect(yarn('install', '--inline-builds')).resolves.toMatch(/Done in \d+s/)
```

As an alternative, I put these steps in a Dockerfile, which does fail on the last step:
```Dockerfile
# Prepare
FROM node:18
WORKDIR /project
COPY package.template.json package.json
RUN yarn set version berry

# Corepack: ENABLED
RUN corepack enable
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn

# Corepack: DISABLED
RUN corepack disable
# With Corepack disabled, we need to get Yarn from somewhere else
RUN npm install -g yarn
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn
```

with the following package.json:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  }
}
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.4
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - /private/var/folders/fk/c9z1tyhj02nfdn9dz_71vjk80000gq/T/xfs-4a2199df/node
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/fk/c9z1tyhj02nfdn9dz_71vjk80000gq/T/xfs-4a2199df/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/Library/Caches/fnm_multishells/59621_1664283223571/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: ^26.6.3 => 26.6.3
```


### Additional context

I managed to get the zip archives from the Yarn cache, as well as the logs from the `yarn pack`:
- with corepack **enabled**:
    - [timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667021/timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip)
    - [corepack-enabled.log](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667046/corepack-enabled.log)
- with corepack **disabled**:
    - [timecop-https-21fab97b94-fbbbc614ae-corepack-disabled.zip](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667049/timecop-https-21fab97b94-fbbbc614ae-corepack-disabled.zip)
    - [corepack-disabled.log](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667050/corepack-disabled.log)

As you can see, the version used for `yarn pack` is different:
- with Corepack _enabled_, it's using v1.22.15
- with Corepack _disabled_, it's using v2+, I think?

Note that I have a global Yarn install from Homebrew:
```sh
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
```

The same happens when Yarn is installed through npm (as per the Dockerfile repro).

Another interesting finding: no matter if Corepack is enabled or disabled, the Yarn binary & version stays the same:
```sh
# From my home directory
# Results are the same from within my project directory, except the version is 3.2.3 there
$ corepack disable
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
$ yarn --version
1.22.19
$ corepack enable
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
$ yarn --version
1.22.19
```

issue.title: [Bug?]: --cwd does not work with relative paths

labels.name: unreproducible
labels.description: This issue cannot be reproduced on master

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When using `--cwd` with a relative path, yarn seems to resolve the relative path twice (or even more times when `.../subdir/subdir` actually is a directory!). So running `yarn --cwd subdir`, it tries to access `.../subdir/subdir` and then it gives an error that the path does not exist.

### To reproduce

```js repro
const { mkdir } = require("fs/promises");

await mkdir("subdir");
await expect(yarn("--cwd", "subdir", "init")).resolves.not.toThrow();
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: Linux 5.15 Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS (Focal Fossa)
    CPU: (4) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3537U CPU @ 2.00GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.14.2 - /tmp/xfs-ebd4110f/node
    Yarn: 3.2.0 - /tmp/xfs-ebd4110f/yarn
    npm: 8.13.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
Hi! 👋

This issue looks stale, and doesn't feature the `reproducible` label - which implies that you didn't provide a working reproduction using [Sherlock](https://yarnpkg.com/advanced/sherlock). As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. Sherlock gives us the ability to check which bugs are still affecting the master branch at any given point, and decreases the amount of code we need to run on our own machines (thus leading to faster bug resolutions). It helps us help you! 😃

If you absolutely *cannot* reproduce a bug on Sherlock (for example because it's a Windows-only issue), a maintainer will have to manually add the `upholded` label. Thanks for helping us triaging our repository! 🌟

issue.title: [Bug?]: yarn create doesn't work with httpsCaFilePath
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

If you have `httpsCaFilePath` in your config, `yarn create` trying to resolve relative path to cert in temp folder:

.yarnrc.yml:
```
httpsCaFilePath: ./some-cert.crt
nodeLinker: node-modules
npmRegistryServer: "https://custom-registry.com"
yarnPath: .yarn/releases/yarn-4.0.0-rc.20.cjs
```

`yarn create playwright`:

➤ YN0027: create-playwright@unknown can't be resolved to a satisfying range
➤ YN0001: Error: ENOENT: no such file or directory, open 'C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\Temp\xfs-cee34bdc\dlx-18200\some-cert.crt'

### To reproduce

yarn config set httpsCaFilePath ./some-cert.crt
yarn create playwright

### Environment

```shell
System:
  OS: Windows 10 10.0.19044
  CPU: (8) x64 11th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1185G7 @ 3.00GHz
  Memory: 7.76 GB / 15.40 GB
Binaries:
  Node: 16.16.0 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\node.EXE
  Yarn: 4.0.0-rc.20 - C:\Program Files (x86)\Yarn\bin\yarn.CMD
  npm: 8.11.0 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.CMD
```


### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: [Bug?]: Module not found: Error: Can't resolve 'x' in 'y' packageExtensions binaries [arm, android win32-x64, darwin, gnu, linux]
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

[Mongodb](https://www.npmjs.com/package/mongodb) has dependencies that are not listed as peer dependencies. I tried to use `packageExtensions` to get around this but I am now getting dozens more errors from two libraries [Snappy](https://www.npmjs.com/package/snappy) and [@mongodb-js/zstd](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@mongodb-js/zstd).

```
➤ YN0000:   in ../../.yarn/cache/@mongodb-js-zstd-npm-1.0.0-1751370982-73e82a30be.zip/node_modules/@mongodb-js/zstd/index.js 89:28-70
➤ YN0000:   Module not found: Error: Can't resolve './zstd.linux-arm-gnueabihf.node' in '/Users/sigex/workdir/backend/lambda/.yarn/cache/@mongodb-js-zstd-npm-1.0.0-1751370982-73e82a30be.zip/node_modules/@mongodb-js/zstd'
```

```
➤ YN0000:   in ../../.yarn/cache/snappy-npm-7.1.2-2cf48206bf-7381485fdd.zip/node_modules/snappy/index.js 1:622-662
➤ YN0000:   Module not found: Error: Can't resolve '@napi-rs/snappy-android-arm64' in '/Users/sigex/workdir/backend/lambda/.yarn/cache/snappy-npm-7.1.2-2cf48206bf-7381485fdd.zip/node_modules/snappy'
```

It looks like it's trying to require all these different binaries for different machines.

My `packageExtensions` is below and it's managed to get most of the warnings to shut up.

```yaml
packageExtensions:
  "mongodb@*":
    dependencies:
      bson-ext: "*"
      kerberos: "*"
      "@mongodb-js/zstd": "*"
      aws4: "*"
      mongodb-core: "*"
      bson: "*"
      node-gyp: "*"
      "mongodb-client-encryption": "*"
    peerDependenciesMeta:
      "@mongodb-js/zstd":
        optional: true
      snappy:
        optional: true
      bson-ext:
        optional: true
      kerberos:
        optional: true
```

### To reproduce

I created a repo here, see branch `mongodb-broken-pnp`.

https://github.com/gruckion/yarn-berry-serverless-workspaces/tree/mongodb-broken-pnp

Run `yarn; yarn package` to reproduce the errors.

```

➤ YN0000: 
➤ YN0000: Packaging lambdas-hello for stage testing (us-east-1)
➤ YN0000: 
➤ YN0000: Warning: in ../../.yarn/__virtual__/mongodb-virtual-904dd890e4/0/cache/mongodb-npm-4.10.0-99903c2c4a-4847fe69b6.zip/node_modules/mongodb/lib/utils.js 993:38-93

issue.body:
### Self-service

When using yarn with pnp linking, the handling of the * in a package.json#exports has a compatibility issue. Mainly, if the * appears in the middle, it fails, but this is supported with node out-of-the-box.

```

yarn
yarn test # works

yarn
yarn test # fails

issue.title: [Bug]: Calling `yarn rebuild` in postinstall calls it infinitely recursively
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When calling `yarn rebuild` in a `postinstall` script, the `rebuild` command will call the `postinstall` script after being finished (or before? doesn't matter), which will call `rebuild` again and do so indefinitely.

This behavior doesn't happen on NPM which I presume does not run `postinstall` after `npm rebuild`, but apparently Yarn does. Since Yarn doesn't provide a way to disable scripts for `rebuild`, I can't do something like `"postinstall": "yarn rebuild --ignore-scripts sharp"`, and disabling it globally via `.yarnrc.yml` would also ruin the purpose.

I know that the doc recommends not to use `postinstall`, but since I'm running my project in a Docker container (Linux + MUSL) with a `node_modules` created with Yarn in local (on Darwin), I have to use this script to rebuild sharp for the `linuxmusl` platform (alongside the `darwin` platform it was originally built with) so that it can run in the container. (Related to #3853)

The reason I made this `postinstall` script is that using `supportedArchitectures` also doesn't work for sharp (which uses .node bindings in itself), but does for `esbuild` (which uses a separate dependency for each platform). This could make another issue maybe?

### To reproduce

This can be reproduced by running `yarn` with the following package.json:
```json
{
  "name": "test",
  "scripts": {
    "postinstall": "yarn rebuild sharp"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "sharp": "^0.31.0"
  },
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.3"
}
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
  OS: macOS 12.4
  CPU: (16) x64 AMD Ryzen 7 3800X 8-Core Processor
Binaries:
  Node: 18.8.0 - /private/var/folders/4_/k05ccxxd13j3n60930rkvz880000gn/T/xfs-c714cf0d/node
  Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/4_/k05ccxxd13j3n60930rkvz880000gn/T/xfs-c714cf0d/yarn
  npm: 8.18.0 - ~/.nix-profile/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

It's my first time using the new Yarn version, I migrated to use the `supportedArchitectures` feature for the Docker platform compatibility issue I had with `esbuild` and `sharp` as described earlier, but sadly it didn't fix it for `sharp` without the `postinstall` script, which itself only works using npm and not yarn. Since it works running `npm` in the `postinstall` script and still using yarn, this isn't a major issue, but still is a bug I felt had to be reported.

issue.title: [Bug?]: Patch isn't applying fully to @rnmapbox/maps

labels.name: can't repro
labels.description: Will soon be closed unless a repro is found

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

```
yarn add @rnmapbox/maps
yarn patch @rnmapbox/maps
cd [tmp folder]
npm i -g typescript
npx tsc --declaration false --noImplicitAny false
cd -
yarn patch-commit -s  [tmp folder]
```

This will create a patch that for some reason adds a `b` directory instead of the `lib` directory thats added from typescript. Further, if you make any changes to `package.json` before patch-commit, those are entirely lost.

### To reproduce

```
yarn add @rnmapbox/maps
yarn patch @rnmapbox/maps
cd [tmp folder]
npm i -g typescript
npx tsc --declaration false --noImplicitAny false
cd -
yarn patch-commit -s  [tmp folder]
```

This will create a patch that for some reason adds a `b` directory instead of the `lib` directory thats added from typescript. Further, if you make any changes to `package.json` before patch-commit, those are entirely lost.

issue.title: Yarn Syntax Error - .yarnrc.yml: SyntaxError: ';' expected

labels.name: waiting for feedback
labels.description: Will autoclose in a while unless more data are provided

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug



I have an angular project with Yarn (3.2.3) installed. While running `yarn run format:check`, it reads .yarnrc.yml file and throws below error:
```
.yarnrc.yml: SyntaxError: ';' expected 
[error]   3 | npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
[error]   4 | npmScopes:
[error] > 5 |   "my-private-repo":
[error]     |                      ^
[error]   6 |     npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
[error]   7 |   ionic:
[error]   8 |     npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
```

### To reproduce

Here is my .yarnrc.yml configuration:
```yaml
yarnPath: ".yarn/releases/yarn-3.2.3.cjs"
nodeLinker: node-modules
npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
npmScopes:
  "my-private-repo":
    npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
  ionic:
    npmRegistryServer: 'SOME_SERVER'
enableStrictSsl: false
httpRetry: 2
httpTimeout: 60000
```
Syntax error is thrown at "my-private-repo" . I figured out that maybe the issue is with the hyphens in that private repository as when I removed that repo, the command passes successfully. I cannot rename that private repo as its a legacy repo. Any clues how to fix this issue ?



### Environment

```shell
Node Version : 14.15.4
Yarn : 3.2.3
macOS : 11.6.5
```


### Additional context

Syntax error is thrown at "my-private-repo" . I figured out that maybe the issue is with the hyphens in that private repository as when I removed that repo, the command passes successfully. I cannot rename that private repo as its a legacy repo. Any clues how to fix this issue ?

issue.title: [Bug?]: Regression error for `yarn dedupe`.

labels.name: reproducible
labels.description: This issue can be successfully reproduced

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

`yarn dedupe --check` shows that there is a package that can be dedupe but running `yarn dedupe` has no effect.
This is a regression bug that worked fine in 3.1.1 but was broken in 3.2.0 until the current main branch.

```
PS F:\babel> yarn dedupe --check
➤ YN0000: ┌ Deduplication step
➤ YN0000: │ eslint@npm:eslint@^8.0.0 can be deduped from eslint@npm:8.0.0 to eslint@npm:8.9.0
➤ YN0000: │ One package can be deduped using the highest strategy
➤ YN0000: └ Completed
```

### To reproduce

#### Sherlock

```js repro
await packageJsonAndInstall({
  dependencies: {
    [`eslint`]: `^8.9.0`,
    [`eslint-8`]: `npm:eslint@^8.0.0`,
  },
});

await yarn(`set`, `resolution`, `eslint-8@npm:eslint@^8.0.0`, `npm:eslint@8.0.0`);

await yarn(`dedupe`);

await expect(yarn(`dedupe`, `--check`))
  .resolves.toBeTruthy();
```

#### Babel repo (latest commit doesn't repro, go back to an older commit such as `41582ee444debf24dc0702cef2919f608d06b235`)

```sh
git clone https://github.com/babel/babel
cd babel
yarn set version stable
yarn dedupe
yarn dedupe --check
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: Windows 10 10.0.22000
    CPU: (24) x64 AMD Ryzen Threadripper 1920X 12-Core Processor
  Binaries:
    Node: 18.3.0 - C:\Users\liuxingbaoyu\AppData\Local\Temp\xfs-fd8c095c\node.CMD

    npm: 8.11.0 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.CMD
```


### Additional context

issue.title: [Bug?]: Patch isn't applying fully to @rnmapbox/maps

labels.name: can't repro
labels.description: Will soon be closed unless a repro is found

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

```
yarn add @rnmapbox/maps
yarn patch @rnmapbox/maps
cd [tmp folder]
npm i -g typescript
npx tsc --declaration false --noImplicitAny false
cd -
yarn patch-commit -s  [tmp folder]
```

This will create a patch that for some reason adds a `b` directory instead of the `lib` directory thats added from typescript. Further, if you make any changes to `package.json` before patch-commit, those are entirely lost.

### To reproduce

```
yarn add @rnmapbox/maps
yarn patch @rnmapbox/maps
cd [tmp folder]
npm i -g typescript
npx tsc --declaration false --noImplicitAny false

yarn patch-commit -s  [tmp folder]
```

issue.title: [Bug?]: peerdependency version being ignored?

labels.name: unreproducible
labels.description: This issue cannot be reproduced on master

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

I am adding this as a bug since the behavior is different from npm.
In short, running the bellow command has different behaviors, npm adds @sentry/angular using the version defined on the peerDependency of @sentry/capacitor@0.9.0 where yarn ignores that version number and uses the latest version of the package.


yarn install @sentry/capacitor@0.9.0 @sentry/angular
```
{
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.3",
  "dependencies": {
    "@sentry/angular": "^7.12.1",
    "@sentry/capacitor": "0.9.0",
  }
}
```

npm install @sentry/capacitor@0.9.0 @sentry/angular
```
{
  "dependencies": {
    "@sentry/angular": "^7.8.1",
    "@sentry/capacitor": "^0.9.0"
  }
}
```

sentry angular is defined as a peer dependency here:
https://github.com/getsentry/sentry-capacitor/blob/0.9.0/package.json#L40

If not a bug, it would be great to know how `yarn` could behave the same as `npm` in this case where users type for example `yarn add @sentry/capacitor @sentry/angular` where @sentry/capacitor has a peer dependency  version lower than the latest release of @sentry/angular.

### To reproduce

yarn install @sentry/capacitor@0.9.0 @sentry/angular

no need to add additional code, the build will break because the types are incompatible with the latest version of @sentry/angular

```js repro
// Sherlock reproduction. For instance:
await packageJsonAndInstall({
  dependencies: {
    [`@sentry/capacitor`]: `0.9.0`,
    [`@sentry/angular`]: ``,
  },
});
```


### Environment

```shell
Same was reproduced by other users on different machines.

  System:
    OS: Windows 10 10.0.22000
    CPU: (12) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-9750H CPU @ 2.60GHz
  Binaries:
    Node: 18.7.0 - ~\AppData\Local\Temp\xfs-da2809f7\node.CMD
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - ~\AppData\Local\Temp\xfs-da2809f7\yarn.CMD
    npm: 8.19.1 - C:\Program Files\nodejs\npm.CMD
```


### Additional context

_No response_

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. issue.title: [Bug?]: Checksum mismatch between corepack and non-corepack installs because of newline in package.json

labels.name: broken-repro
labels.description: The reproduction in this issue is broken

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When switching between `corepack enable` and `corepack disable`, Yarn complains about a checksum mismatch on a package installed with the `git:` protocol. This seems to be because the packing happens with a different version of Yarn, which adds / removes an extra newline at the end of the `package.json` of the dependency.

I had a similar problem before with Yarn 3.2.1 (adding a `packageManager` field to the package.json, IIRC). I upgraded to v3.2.3, which should have resolved that problem, but now I have this.

### To reproduce

Steps to reproduce:
- Create a new, empty directory
- Create the following `package.json`:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  }
}
```
- `yarn set version berry` or `yarn set version from sources` (I could reproduce with both)
- `corepack disable`
- `yarn`
- `corepack enable` (you can switch these around - first enable, then disable fails for me too)
- `rm -rf node_modules`
- `yarn cache clean --all`
- `yarn` -> fails with `YN0018: │ timecop@https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#commit=d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761: The remote archive doesn't match the expected checksum`

I tried to make a reproducible case with Sherlock, as suggested - I made this, but it works fine there:
```js repro
const path = require('path')
const {execFile} = require(`child_process`)
const {promisify} = require(`util`)

const execFileP = promisify(execFile)

async function exec(execPath, args = [], opts = {}) {
  try {
    const {stdout} = await execFileP(execPath, args, opts)
    return stdout
  } catch (error) {
    error.message += `\n${error.stdout}`;
    throw error;
  }
};

await packageJson({
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  },
})

const nodePath = process.argv[0]
const corepackPath = path.resolve(nodePath, '../corepack')

await yarn('set', 'version', 'berry')
await exec(corepackPath, ['enable'])
await yarn('install', '--inline-builds')

await exec(corepackPath, ['disable'])
await exec('rm', ['-rf', 'node_modules'])
await yarn('cache', 'clean', '--all')
await expect(yarn('install', '--inline-builds')).resolves.toMatch(/Done in \d+s/)
```

As an alternative, I put these steps in a Dockerfile, which does fail on the last step:
```Dockerfile
# Prepare
FROM node:18
WORKDIR /project
COPY package.template.json package.json
RUN yarn set version berry

# Corepack: ENABLED
RUN corepack enable
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn

# Corepack: DISABLED
RUN corepack disable
# With Corepack disabled, we need to get Yarn from somewhere else
RUN npm install -g yarn
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn
```

with the following package.json:
```json
{
  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  }
}
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.4
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - /private/var/folders/fk/c9z1tyhj02nfdn9dz_71vjk80000gq/T/xfs-4a2199df/node
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/fk/c9z1tyhj02nfdn9dz_71vjk80000gq/T/xfs-4a2199df/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/Library/Caches/fnm_multishells/59621_1664283223571/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: ^26.6.3 => 26.6.3
```


### Additional context

I managed to get the zip archives from the Yarn cache, as well as the logs from the `yarn pack`:
- with corepack **enabled**:
    - [timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667021/timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip)
    - [corepack-enabled.log](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667046/corepack-enabled.log)
- with corepack **disabled**:
    - [timecop-https-21fab97b94-fbbbc614ae-corepack-disabled.zip](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667049/timecop-https-21fab97b94-fbbbc614ae-corepack-disabled.zip)
    - [corepack-disabled.log](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667050/corepack-disabled.log)

As you can see, the version used for `yarn pack` is different:
- with Corepack _enabled_, it's using v1.22.15
- with Corepack _disabled_, it's using v2+, I think?

Note that I have a global Yarn install from Homebrew:
```sh
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
```

The same happens when Yarn is installed through npm (as per the Dockerfile repro).

Another interesting finding: no matter if Corepack is enabled or disabled, the Yarn binary & version stays the same:
```sh
# From my home directory
# Results are the same from within my project directory, except the version is 3.2.3 there
$ corepack disable
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
$ yarn --version
1.22.19
$ corepack enable
$ which yarn
/opt/homebrew/bin/yarn
$ yarn --version
1.22.19
```

comment.body:
The reproduction case in your issue seems broken (ie it neither pass nor fail due to throwing an unmanaged exception):
```
Error: spawn /usr/bin/corepack ENOENT

    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (node:internal/child_process:283:19)
    at onErrorNT (node:internal/child_process:478:16)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:83:21)
```

Remember: any non-Jest exceptions will cause the test to be reported as broken. If you expect something to pass without throwing, you must wrap it into something like `await expect(...).resolves.toBeTruthy()`. If you instead expect something to throw, you need to wrap it into `await expect(...).rejects.toThrow()`.

issue.title: [Bug?]: `fs.promises.open` doesn't throw `ENOENT` when path doesn't exist

labels.name: reproducible
labels.description: This issue can be successfully reproduced

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

`fs.promises.open` resolves with a `FileHandle` object when given an non-existing file path.

The correct behavior should be throwing an error with code `ENOENT`.

### To reproduce

```js repro
await packageJsonAndInstall({
  dependencies: {
    'tslib': '*',
  },
})

const realPath = await node(`require.resolve('tslib/package.json')`)
const fakePath = `${realPath}.fake`

const result = await node(`
  require('fs/promises')
    .open(${JSON.stringify(fakePath)})
    .then(() => 'resolved')
    .catch((err) => \`rejected: \${err.code}\`)
`)
expect(result).toBe('rejected: ENOENT')
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
  OS: Linux 5.10 Alpine Linux
  CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6920HQ CPU @ 2.90GHz
Binaries:
  Node: 16.17.1 - /tmp/xfs-28478f54/node
  Yarn: 3.2.3 - /tmp/xfs-28478f54/yarn
  npm: 8.15.0 - /usr/local/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

  "dependencies": {
    "timecop": "git+https://github.com/jamesarosen/Timecop.js.git#d421df9b00386266bda93eb9c2ea15fedc888761"
  },
})

const nodePath = process.argv[0]
const corepackPath = path.resolve(nodePath, '../corepack')

await yarn('set', 'version', 'berry')
await exec(corepackPath, ['enable'])
await yarn('install', '--inline-builds')

await exec(corepackPath, ['disable'])
await exec('rm', ['-rf', 'node_modules'])
await yarn('cache', 'clean', '--all')
await expect(yarn('install', '--inline-builds')).resolves.toMatch(/Done in \d+s/)
```

As an alternative, I put these steps in a Dockerfile, which does fail on the last step:
```Dockerfile
# Prepare
FROM node:18
WORKDIR /project
COPY package.template.json package.json
RUN yarn set version berry

# Corepack: ENABLED
RUN corepack enable
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn

# Corepack: DISABLED
RUN corepack disable
RUN npm install -g yarn
RUN rm -rf node_modules
RUN yarn cache clean --all
RUN yarn --version
RUN yarn
```

### Environment

```shell

    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:

    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/fk/c9z1tyhj02nfdn9dz_71vjk80000gq/T/xfs-4a2199df/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/Library/Caches/fnm_multishells/59621_1664283223571/bin/npm
  npmPackages:
    jest: ^26.6.3 => 26.6.3
```


### Additional context

I managed to get the zip archives from the Yarn cache, as well as the logs from the `yarn pack`:
- with corepack **enabled**:
    - [timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667021/timecop-https-21fab97b94-b209b91b1f-corepack-enabled.zip)

    - [corepack-disabled.log](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/files/9667050/corepack-disabled.log)

comment.body:
The reproduction case in your issue seems broken (ie it neither pass nor fail due to throwing an unmanaged exception):
```
Error: spawn /usr/bin/corepack ENOENT

    at Process.ChildProcess._handle.onexit (node:internal/child_process:283:19)
    at onErrorNT (node:internal/child_process:478:16)
    at processTicksAndRejections (node:internal/process/task_queues:83:21)
```

Remember: any non-Jest exceptions will cause the test to be reported as broken. If you expect something to pass without throwing, you must wrap it into something like `await expect(...).resolves.toBeTruthy()`. If you instead expect something to throw, you need to wrap it into `await expect(...).rejects.toThrow()`.

issue.title: [Bug?]: --cwd does not work with relative paths

labels.name: unreproducible
labels.description: This issue cannot be reproduced on master

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When using `--cwd` with a relative path, yarn seems to resolve the relative path twice (or even more times when `.../subdir/subdir` actually is a directory!). So running `yarn --cwd subdir`, it tries to access `.../subdir/subdir` and then it gives an error that the path does not exist.

### To reproduce

```js repro
const { mkdir } = require("fs/promises");

await mkdir("subdir");
await expect(yarn("--cwd", "subdir", "init")).resolves.not.toThrow();
```

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: Linux 5.15 Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS (Focal Fossa)
    CPU: (4) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-3537U CPU @ 2.00GHz
  Binaries:

    Yarn: 3.2.0 - /tmp/xfs-ebd4110f/yarn
    npm: 8.13.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.14.2/bin/npm
```

_No response_

As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. issue.title: [Bug?]: install cache didn't save on cacheFolder
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

install cache didn't save on cacheFolder

### To reproduce

1. run yarn install

cached file should save in `T:\cache\yarn-cache`
but it save at `C:\Users\User\AppData\Local\Yarn\Berry\cache`


### Environment

```shell
yarn-3.2.2
```


### Additional context

~/.yarnrc.yml
```
npmRegistryServer: "https://registry.npmjs.org/"
cacheFolder: "T:\\cache\\yarn-cache"
enableColors: true
nodeLinker: node-modules

plugins:
  - path: "C:/Users/User/.yarn/plugins/@yarnpkg/plugin-workspace-tools.cjs"
    spec: "@yarnpkg/plugin-workspace-tools"
  - path: "C:/Users/User/.yarn/plugins/@yarnpkg/plugin-interactive-tools.cjs"
    spec: "@yarnpkg/plugin-interactive-tools"

```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/167966/184725032-c55ff5d5-1f98-4c2c-a895-16513a55f8d1.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/167966/184726697-34a11ffd-8305-4e92-9f75-2b4793846f4a.png)

issue.title: [Bug?]: `y up` does not upgrade package when using `latest`/`*` version pin
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [x] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

Given a package.json with e.g. `"dependencies": { "just-extend": "latest" }`, a `yarn.lock` with `"just-extend@latest":\n version: 6.0.0`, and [a released version that could be upgraded to](https://www.npmjs.com/package/just-extend), `yarn up` does nothing. `yarn up just-extend@latest` similarly has no effect. `yarn up just-extend` _does_ upgrade the package, but changes the version in `package.json`, which I don't want: the upgrade should affect `yarn.lock` only. It appears that the version glob `*` has the same issue.

(The specific package doesn't matter; I've reproduced this with many others)

I just upgraded to yarn berry. `yarn upgrade` was previously upgrading these packages on Yarn Classic. I've looked in the release notes, in the migration guide, issues and discussions here, everything; nothing notes that the behaviour of `y up` has changed to no longer support the `latest` tag. I've also seen nothing about yarn now enforcing a specific version pinning strategy in package.json.

Am I missing something? Did these things change? Where was it noted (e.g. release notes?) or discussed?

### To reproduce

package.json
```
{
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.4",
  "dependencies": {
    "just-extend": "latest"
  }
}
```

yarn.lock

```
# This file is generated by running "yarn install" inside your project.
# Manual changes might be lost - proceed with caution!

__metadata:
  version: 6
  cacheKey: 8

"just-extend@npm:latest":
  version: 6.0.0
  resolution: "just-extend@npm:6.0.0"
  checksum: f766424f4d119bc60a6d27d817ca998cdf3aefe20df3309303540970eebae60efd370f0192ba9fa6a826dd7df2872fb7c9e24f0061fbda0156b90b133bd97e49
  languageName: node
  linkType: hard

"root-workspace-0b6124@workspace:.":
  version: 0.0.0-use.local
  resolution: "root-workspace-0b6124@workspace:."
  dependencies:
    just-extend: latest
  languageName: unknown
  linkType: soft
```

Then run `yarn up`. It should upgrade to version 6.1.1

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 13.0
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 19.0.0 - /private/var/folders/00/dd4ntv795rx101d_l6wnvdyc0000gn/T/xfs-165fd651/node
    Yarn: 3.2.4 - /private/var/folders/00/dd4ntv795rx101d_l6wnvdyc0000gn/T/xfs-165fd651/yarn
    npm: 8.19.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v19.0.0/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: [Bug?]: Unable to run yarn with read-only filesystem, requires creating ~/.cache directory

labels.name: waiting for feedback
labels.description: Will autoclose in a while unless more data are provided

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

It seems like Yarn uses `~/.cache` as a cache directory. I can't find this being documented anywhere, and I also can't find any way to change it. We were always using Yarn v1 in a Docker environment where the file system is read-only except for /tmp, and ran into this issue when upgrading.

### To reproduce

```
www-data@0f66918dbde8:/data$ yarn

OK

issue.title: [Bug?]: `y up` does not upgrade package when using `latest`/`*` version pin
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [x] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

Given a package.json with e.g. `"dependencies": { "just-extend": "latest" }`, a `yarn.lock` with `"just-extend@latest":\n version: 6.0.0`, and [a released version that could be upgraded to](https://www.npmjs.com/package/just-extend), `yarn up` does nothing. `yarn up just-extend@latest` similarly has no effect. `yarn up just-extend` _does_ upgrade the package, but changes the version in `package.json`, which I don't want: the upgrade should affect `yarn.lock` only. It appears that the version glob `*` has the same issue.

(The specific package doesn't matter; I've reproduced this with many others)

I just upgraded to yarn berry. `yarn upgrade` was previously upgrading these packages on Yarn Classic. I've looked in the release notes, in the migration guide, issues and discussions here, everything; nothing notes that the behaviour of `y up` has changed to no longer support the `latest` tag. I've also seen nothing about yarn now enforcing a specific version pinning strategy in package.json.

Am I missing something? Did these things change? Where was it noted (e.g. release notes?) or discussed?

### To reproduce

package.json
```
{
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.4",
  "dependencies": {
    "just-extend": "latest"
  }
}
```

yarn.lock

```
# This file is generated by running "yarn install" inside your project.
# Manual changes might be lost - proceed with caution!

__metadata:
  version: 6
  cacheKey: 8

"just-extend@npm:latest":
  version: 6.0.0
  resolution: "just-extend@npm:6.0.0"
  checksum: f766424f4d119bc60a6d27d817ca998cdf3aefe20df3309303540970eebae60efd370f0192ba9fa6a826dd7df2872fb7c9e24f0061fbda0156b90b133bd97e49
  languageName: node
  linkType: hard

"root-workspace-0b6124@workspace:.":
  version: 0.0.0-use.local
  resolution: "root-workspace-0b6124@workspace:."
  dependencies:
    just-extend: latest
  languageName: unknown
  linkType: soft
```

Then run `yarn up`. It should upgrade to version 6.1.1

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 13.0
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 19.0.0 - /private/var/folders/00/dd4ntv795rx101d_l6wnvdyc0000gn/T/xfs-165fd651/node
    Yarn: 3.2.4 - /private/var/folders/00/dd4ntv795rx101d_l6wnvdyc0000gn/T/xfs-165fd651/yarn
    npm: 8.19.2 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v19.0.0/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

issue.title: [Bug?]: yarn pack doesn't include all the files

labels.name: reproducible
labels.description: This issue can be successfully reproduced

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

`yarn pack` doesn't include all the files for the [mediasoup](https://github.com/versatica/mediasoup/) project. This only happens on Yarn v3. Yarn v1 and NPM pack them correctly. This leads to install failure when this package is installed directly from GitHub. 

On v3, `yarn pack` will only include files, if they are directly specified or match a pattern in `package.json#files`. Specifying just the folder name doesn't work:

It won't pack all the files in `worker/src` and `worker/include`
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include",
    "worker/src",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",
    "worker/meson.build",
    "worker/meson_options.txt",
    "npm-scripts.js"
  ],
```

But if try wildcard patterns, it includes them:
```
  "files": [
    "node/lib",
    "worker/include/**/*",
    "worker/src/**/*",
    "worker/subprojects/*.wrap",
    "worker/Makefile",

issue.title: [Bug?]: React rendering warnings from upgrade-interactive
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

This bug relates to the upgrade-interactive UI, which is built with React (via [Ink](https://github.com/vadimdemedes/ink)).

It's throwing React rendering errors about unique keys, which is pretty common in React apps. I think this particular issue is rare, but I happen to have a set of available upgrades that provokes it.

Here's the symptom (which appears above the interactive terminal UI):

```
Warning: Encountered two children with the same key, `^7.0.0`. Keys should be unique so that components maintain their identity across updates. Non-unique keys may cause children to be duplicated and/or omitted — the behavior is unsupported and could change in a future version.
    in $5 (created by W)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by W)
    in W (created by ne)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box (created by m4)
    in m4 (created by ne)
    in ne
    in ink-box (created by Box)
    in Box
    in Unknown
    in kx
    in InternalApp
```

And here's what it's rendering:

```
 Press <up>/<down> to select packages.            Press <enter> to install.
 Press <left>/<right> to select versions.         Press <ctrl+c> to abort.

? Pick the packages you want to upgrade.          Current          Range            Latest

 > @storybook/react-vite ----------------------- ◉ ^7.0.0-alpha.… ◯ ^7.0.0 ------- ◯ ^7.0.0 -------
   @storybook/react ---------------------------- ◉ ^7.0.0-alpha.… ◯ ^7.0.0 ------- ◯ ^6.5.13 ------
```

(Notice that the string `^7.0.0` appears a few times)

Skimming through [upgrade-interactive.tsx](https://github.com/yarnpkg/berry/blob/%40yarnpkg/shell/3.2.4/packages/plugin-interactive-tools/sources/commands/upgrade-interactive.tsx), I don't see many explicit keys provided (`key={something_here}`), so perhaps this relates to the way Ink behaves when they're left out. (using the contained text instead?)

### To reproduce

Minimal package.json:
```json
{
  "devDependencies": {
    "@storybook/react": "^7.0.0-alpha.44",
    "@storybook/react-vite": "^7.0.0-alpha.44"
  },
  "packageManager": "yarn@3.2.4"
}
```

`yarn set version stable`
`yarn plugin import interactive-tools`
`yarn install`
`yarn upgrade-interactive`

This repro also depends on the available package versions - I imagine the issue may go away when Storybook begins stable 7.0.x releases.

### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 13.0
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.17.1 - /private/var/folders/f1/5hh6j9fd7mv6dm1hdrzzh7_w0000gn/T/xfs-e4bcc5e6/node
    Yarn: 3.2.4 - /private/var/folders/f1/5hh6j9fd7mv6dm1hdrzzh7_w0000gn/T/xfs-e4bcc5e6/yarn
    npm: 8.15.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.17.1/bin/npm
```


### Additional context

_No response_

comment.body:
Hi! 👋

This issue looks stale, and doesn't feature the `reproducible` label - which implies that you didn't provide a working reproduction using [Sherlock](https://yarnpkg.com/advanced/sherlock). As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. Sherlock gives us the ability to check which bugs are still affecting the master branch at any given point, and decreases the amount of code we need to run on our own machines (thus leading to faster bug resolutions). It helps us help you! 😃

If you absolutely *cannot* reproduce a bug on Sherlock (for example because it's a Windows-only issue), a maintainer will have to manually add the `upholded` label. Thanks for helping us triaging our repository! 🌟

issue.title: [Bug?]: unexpected to evaluate the devDependencies of a dependence package from git source even when there is no build script in it.

labels.name: reproducible
labels.description: This issue can be successfully reproduced

issue.body:
### Self-service

- [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

When:
- use `yarn` command to install a dependence package from Git Source;
- there are **no build scripts** in the git package; 
- there is a dev dependence package whose descriptor is `"workspace:*"`, and it's not hosted in the repository of the git package.

what happens:
- `yarn` failed with YN0058.
```
 YN0058: │ git-source-package@git+ssh://git@github.com:AmyFoxFN/yarn-demo-git-source-package.git#commit=b367f12603cbc45eb3db49d44d6363e928f6b6d5: Packing the package failed (exit code 1, logs can be found here: /private/var/folders/vk/jl551z8j4157nvxvv9wj1sqr0000gn/T/xfs-a1cb5754/pack.log)
```
- errors in pack.log.
```
ct [Error]: local-workspace@workspace:*: No local workspace found for this range
    at xVe (/Users/didi/.node/corepack/yarn/3.2.0/yarn.js:712:37482)
    at Xa.triggerHook (/Users/didi/.node/corepack/yarn/3.2.0/yarn.js:396:3373)
    at Yue (/Users/didi/.node/corepack/yarn/3.2.0/yarn.js:712:30939)
    at /Users/didi/.node/corepack/yarn/3.2.0/yarn.js:712:30487 {
  reportExtra: undefined,
  reportCode: 21
}
```


### To reproduce
```js repro
await expect(packageJsonAndInstall({
  dependencies: {
    [`git-source-package`]: `git+ssh://git@github.com:AmyFoxFN/yarn-demo-git-source-package.git#b367f12603cbc45eb3db49d44d6363e928f6b6d5`,
  }
})).resolves.toBeTruthy()
```
**It seems the default sherlock reproduction env could not install packages by git+ssh. You may need to use my own demo to reproduce:**
- [the git source package](https://github.com/AmyFoxFN/yarn-demo-git-source-package)
- [the demo of installing the git package](https://github.com/AmyFoxFN/yarn-demo-install)

### Environment

```shell

    CPU: (12) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-9750H CPU @ 2.60GHz

```

Related issue #1915

comment.body:
Hi! 👋

This issue looks stale, and doesn't feature the `reproducible` label - which implies that you didn't provide a working reproduction using [Sherlock](https://yarnpkg.com/advanced/sherlock). As a result, it'll be closed in a few days unless a maintainer explicitly vouches for it or you edit your first post to include a formal reproduction (you can use the [playground](http://yarnpkg.com/playground) for that).

Note that we require Sherlock reproductions for long-lived issues (rather than standalone git repositories or similar) because we're a small team. Sherlock gives us the ability to check which bugs are still affecting the master branch at any given point, and decreases the amount of code we need to run on our own machines (thus leading to faster bug resolutions). It helps us help you! 😃

If you absolutely *cannot* reproduce a bug on Sherlock (for example because it's a Windows-only issue), a maintainer will have to manually add the `upholded` label. Thanks for helping us triaging our repository! 🌟

issue.title: [Bug?]: Duplicate same version dependency when parents peerDependencies are different
issue.body: ### Self-service - [ ] I'd be willing to implement a fix ### Describe the bug | 1st level dependency | `react-draggable` version range | `peerDependencies` | |---|---|---| | [react-grid-layout@1.3.4](https://github.com/react-grid-layout/react-grid-layout) | `^4.0.0` | `{ "react": ">= 16.3.0", "react-dom": ">= 16.3.0" }` | | [react-resizable@1.4.5](https://github.com/react-grid-layout/react-resizable) | `^4.0.3` | `{ "react": ">= 16.3" }` | ```shell ⋊> ~/w/r/e/test-yarn3-duplicates on master ⨯ yarn why react-draggable -R └─ test-yarn3-duplicates@workspace:. └─ react-grid-layout@npm:1.3.4 [8f25d] (via npm:^1.3.4 [8f25d]) ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [6c42a] (via npm:^4.0.0 [6c42a]) └─ react-resizable@npm:3.0.4 [6c42a] (via npm:^3.0.4 [6c42a]) └─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [5d025] (via npm:^4.0.3 [5d025]) ``` ```shell ⋊> ~/w/r/e/test-yarn3-duplicates on master ⨯ yarn info -AR --virtuals react-draggable ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 │ ├─ Instances: 2 │ ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ │ │ └─ Dependencies │ ├─ clsx@npm:^1.1.1 → npm:1.2.1 │ └─ prop-types@npm:^15.8.1 → npm:15.8.1 │ ├─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [5d025] │ ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ │ │ └─ Peer dependencies │ ├─ @types/react-dom@* → ✘ │ ├─ @types/react@* → ✘ │ ├─ react-dom@>= 16.3.0 → ✘ │ └─ react@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 │ └─ react-draggable@npm:4.4.5 [6c42a] ├─ Version: 4.4.5 │ └─ Peer dependencies ├─ @types/react-dom@* → ✘ ├─ @types/react@* → ✘ ├─ react-dom@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 [8f25d] └─ react@>= 16.3.0 → npm:17.0.2 ``` Webpack stats modules ([full bundle analysis](https://bit.ly/3EIdKKK)): ### To reproduce Example repo: https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates Happy to add some reproducible tests if need it ;) ### Environment ```shell System: OS: macOS 12.5.1 CPU: (8) arm64 Apple M1 Pro Binaries: Node: 18.7.0 - /private/var/folders/wf/b3whd19d2hs648_qm9tv046h0000gp/T/xfs-7b5b57ae/node Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/wf/b3whd19d2hs648_qm9tv046h0000gp/T/xfs-7b5b57ae/yarn ``` ### Additional context I was able to workaround the problem using `packageExtensions`: 1. https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates/pull/6 2. https://github.com/relative-ci/fix-yarn3-duplicates/pull/8

issue.title: [Bug?]: `yarn workspace version apply` removes deferred versions for other packages
issue.body:
### Self-service

- [X] I'd be willing to implement a fix

### Describe the bug

I have a workspace that has two packages which do not share a release cycle.

I'm using deferred versioning on the packages with `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version <strategy> --deferred`, which creates `.yarn/versions/<hash>.yml` files defining the strategy just for my target workspace, as I would expect.

When I run `yarn workspace <workspaceName> version apply`, the `package.json` file for the specified workspace is updated. As expected, the `package.json` for the other workspaces has not changed. However, the `.yarn/versions` files have removed the other deferred changes.

### To reproduce

I created a minimal repo using yarn berry with a workspace: https://github.com/NikkiDelRosso/yarn-workspace-version-deferred-issue

1. Clone the repo above
2. Run `yarn workspace package-b version apply`
3. See that the `packages/package-b/package.json` version number has been bumped
4. See that the `packages/package-a/package.json` version number has not changed (this is expected)
5. See that the `package-a: patch` line in in `.yarn/versions/27f417a6.yml` has been removed
6. Run `yarn workspace package-a version apply`
7. Receive a message indicating that there is no version bump available for the workspace (even though it should have had been bumped for a patch)


### Environment

```shell
System:
    OS: macOS 12.5.1
    CPU: (10) arm64 Apple M1 Pro
  Binaries:
    Node: 16.15.1 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/node
    Yarn: 3.2.3 - /private/var/folders/kc/rkdxxgzx4q1b4cq6mpm343100000gn/T/xfs-80d59fb3/yarn
    npm: 8.11.0 - ~/.nvm/versions/node/v16.15.1/bin/npm
```
